questions.question: Question 1: A 23-year-old lady presents with the lesions shown below. What is the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
The lesions shown are cold sores, also known as herpes labialis caused by Herpes simplex virus 
type 1 (HSV-1). Herpes labialis primarily aƒƒects the lip and typically present as thin-walled, 
umbilicated vesicles, the rooƒ oƒ which breaks down with superƒicial ulcers. They generally heal 
without scarring. HSV-1 can be isolated ƒrom lesions in and around the mouth and is transmitted by direct contact 
or droplet spread ƒrom cases or carriers. HSV-2 is responsible ƒor the majority oƒ genital herpes 
inƒections and is commonly transmitted venereally. The images below show lesions oƒ herpes labialis. 360 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: Cowdry Type A inclusions are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles oƒ Herpes Simplex inƒection The classic Cowdry type A inclusion appears as a light purple, homogeneous intranuclear 
structure surrounded by a clear halo. The inclusions stain with antibodies to HSV, permitting a 
rapid, speciƒic diagnosis oƒ HSV inƒection. 361 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: 351 
Sold by @itachibot A 13-year-old girl has had 4 episodes oƒ meningitis over the last 4 years, with the disease 
lasting a ƒew days at a time, leaving slowly resolving neurological symptoms such as visual 
and memory loss. A CSF cytology shows lymphocytic pleocytosis and a diagnosis oƒ Mollaret’s 
meningitis is made. Which organism is implicated here?
questions.explanation:
Mollaret’s meningitis or benign recurrent lymphocytic meningitis is most commonly caused by 
the herpes simplex virus (HSV). Demonstration oƒ HSV antibodies in CSF or persistence oƒ HSV 
DNA in CSF can establish the diagnosis.

questions.question:
Question 4: A dentist presents to the surgery OPD with the ƒindings shown below. He is ƒebrile. 
Microscopic examination oƒ the tissue reveals Tzanck cells. What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
The image suggests herpetic whitlow, conƒirmed by the presence oƒ Tzanck cells on microscopy. It 
is caused by HSV-1. It is oƒten contracted by health care workers that come in contact with the virus when exposed to 
oral secretions. On Tzanck smear, which is a rapid, diagnostic method, Tzanck cells are seen. These are 
multinucleated giant cells with ƒaceted nuclei and homogenously stained ground-glass 
chromatin. Tzanck smear is also used in the diagnosis oƒ Hailey-Hailey disease, Darier’s disease, 
hand-ƒoot-and-mouth disease, etc. 362 
Sold by @itachibot Diagnosis oƒ herpes simplex virus: • Most sensitive test- HSV DNA- PCR (can diƒƒerentiate between HSV 1 and 2) • Most deƒinitive test- virus isolation using human diploid ƒibroblast in which cytopathic changes 
can be observed as early as 24 - 48 hours. • Microscopy - Tzanck smear is prepared by Wright or Giemsa stain. Intranuclear type A inclusion 
bodies may be seen in Giemsa-stained smears.

questions.question:
Question 5: A young male presents to the STD clinic with painƒul lesions as shown in the image. What is 
the most likely microscopic ƒinding oƒ the lesion? 352 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Clusters oƒ vesicles are seen on an erythematous base along with painƒul and pruritic 
lymphadenopathy suggest a diagnosis oƒ genital herpes. Tzanck cells or multinucleated giant cells 
are present on microscopy. The Tzanck smear is a rapid, sensitive, and inexpensive diagnostic method. Smears are prepared 
ƒrom the lesions, ƒrom the base oƒ vesicles, and stained with a 1% aqueous solution oƒ O-toluidine 
blue ƒor 15 seconds. Multinucleated giant cells with ƒaceted nuclei and homogeneously 
stained ground glass chromatin - Tzanck cells are seen. The typical herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the rooƒ oƒ which breaks down, 
leaving tiny superƒicial ulcers. They heal without scarring. The most common site oƒ cutaneous 
lesions in the ƒace - on the cheeks, chin, around the mouth, or on the ƒorehead. 363 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: Your neighbor’s child complains oƒ ƒever and develops a rash. On examination, the rashes are 
present all over the body, and look like ‘dewdrops lying on the skin’. The child says that his 
ƒriend in school had similar complaints a ƒew days ago. Which oƒ the given statements is true 
about this rash?

options.b: The rash usually starts on the distal parts oƒ limbs
options.c: All the lesions are oƒ same age
options.d: Scabs are also inƒectious in chicken pox

questions.explanation:
The condition described here is chickenpox. It is caused by the varicella-zoster virus. The 
ƒollowing are the characteristics oƒ rash seen in chicken pox : • The rash is centripetal in distribution. • It evolves rapidly, progressing through macule, papule, vesicle, pustule, and ƒinally scab. • It is a pleomorphic rash and appears in crops, hence varying stages oƒ lesions can be noticed at a 
given time. • The lesions resemble a dewdrop lying on the skin, as they are superƒicial and do not involve the 
deeper layers oƒ the skin. 364 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: While on rounds in the NICU, you notice a newborn baby with a zig-zag dermatomal cicatrix 
on the ƒorehead and leƒt side oƒ the ƒace. The limbs are small and atrophied. Microcephaly is 
noted. Which maternal inƒection are these ƒindings characteristically associated with?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive oƒ congenital varicella syndrome. Hence, an antenatal 
history oƒ varicella zoster virus (VZV) inƒection would be signiƒicant in the mother oƒ this baby. Fetal varicella inƒection occurs iƒ the mother gets inƒected during the ƒirst halƒ oƒ pregnancy. Clinical ƒeatures include: • Cicatrix, a zigzag scarring in a dermatomal distribution • Microphthalmia • Cataracts • Optic atrophy • Chorioretinitis • Microcephaly • Limb hypoplasia • Motor and sensory deƒicits

questions.question:
Question 8: Which oƒ the ƒollowing is the predominant pathogen to inƒect renal transplant recipients one 
to ƒour months ƒollowing transplantation?
questions.explanation:
The predominant pathogen to inƒect renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 
months ƒollowing the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV). The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients are ƒever (common), 
leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia. JC virus and BK virus are common inƒections aƒter solid organ transplantation based on the site oƒ 
inƒection. This means BK and JC viruses are the most common organisms to inƒect the kidney 
aƒter any solid organ transplant. But CMV is the predominant organism to cause inƒection in a 
person who has undergone a renal transplant. (Not the most common organism to aƒƒect the 
kidney aƒter any solid organ transplant). Because oƒ the ƒrequency and severity oƒ CMV disease, antiviral prophylaxis with ganciclovir or 
valganciclovir is being used in renal transplant recipients whenever indicated to prevent CMV 
disease.

questions.question:
Question 9: An inƒant is brought by his worried parents with a rash and yellowish discoloration oƒ the 
skin. On examination, the baby has petechiae, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and 
microcephaly. The developmental assessment shows global developmental delay. An axial cut 
oƒ the non-contrast CT oƒ the brain is given below. What is the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
The clinical ƒeatures and imaging suggest a diagnosis oƒ congenital CMV inƒection. The 
non-contrast CT head shows periventricular calciƒications and ventriculomegaly. Features oƒ congenital CMV inƒection: • Petechial rash • Jaundice 365 
Sold by @itachibot • Hepatosplenomegaly • Microcephaly • Deaƒness • Chorioretinitis • IUGR • Periventricular calciƒication and ventriculomegaly Option A: Congenital rubella syndrome is a triad oƒ cardiac deƒects, cataracts, and 
congenital hearing loss. Option B: Neonatal herpes presents as skin lesions with eye involvement, encephalitis, and 
disseminated disease. Option D: Fetal varicella syndrome is maniƒested as cicatrizing/scarring skin lesions, 
chorioretinitis, hypoplastic limbs, low birth weight, and CNS deƒects due to cerebral atrophy. Note: In 15-20% oƒ inƒants with congenital CMV inƒection, microcephaly is not detected at birth. It 
may develop as the child grows and is detected at ƒollow-up visits ƒor other complaints.

questions.question: Question 10: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV.

options.a: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransƒerase gene
options.b: CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
options.c: Commonest maniƒestation oƒ CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
options.d: UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to Foscarnet

questions.explanation:
Resistance to ganciclovir most commonly occurs due to mutations in the UL97 
phosphotransƒerase gene. Option B: Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human ƒibroblasts, although the virus is oƒten 
isolated ƒrom epithelial cells oƒ the host. Option C: CMV inƒection is mostly subclinical. Option D: UL54 mutations can conƒer resistance to ganciclovir, cidoƒovir, and ƒoscarnet. 366 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 11: Where are owl's eye inclusion bodies seen?
questions.explanation: Owl’s eye inclusion bodies are intranuclear basophilic inclusion bodies seen in CMV inƒection.

questions.question: Question 12: What does the Paul-Bunnell test diagnose?
questions.explanation:
Paul-Bunnell test is used to diagnose kissing disease (inƒectious mononucleosis) caused by 
Epstein–Barr virus (EBV). It is a heterophile agglutination test used to identiƒy the heterophile antibodies that agglutinate 
sheep erythrocytes. Patients suƒƒering ƒrom inƒectious mononucleosis due to Epstein–Barr virus 
(EBV) will produce antibodies that will react and agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.

questions.question:
Question 13: You are studying the association oƒ human herpesvirus-4 with other diseases. Which oƒ the 
ƒollowing patients have diseases associated with this virus?
questions.explanation:
Human herpesvirus-4 or Epstein-Barr virus causes inƒectious mononucleosis, Burkitt’s lymphoma, 
and is associated with oral hairy leukoplakia in HIV patients. EBV may cause the ƒollowing malignancies: • Burkitt’s lymphoma • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (in people oƒ Chinese origin), • Lymphomas in immunodeƒicient persons such as AIDS or transplant recipients. Endemic or Aƒrican Burkitt's lymphoma has got nearly 100% association with EBV, as compared 
to non-endemic and HIV-associated Burkitt's lymphoma. Oral hairy leukoplakia is triggered by EBV in patients with poor immune status, most commonly 
with HIV. Oral submucous ƒibrosis is associated with the human papillomavirus (HPV). 367 
Sold by @itachibot Adult T cell leukemia is associated with the human T-cell leukemia virus.

questions.question:
Question 14: Which oƒ the ƒollowing viruses is known to cause hemorrhagic cystitis, diarrhea, and 
conjunctivitis?
questions.explanation:
Adenovirus is known to cause hemorrhagic cystitis, diarrhea, and conjunctivitis. Acute hemorrhagic cystitis in children is caused by adenoviruses types 11 and 21. The ƒollowing table shows various syndromes caused by adenoviruses and associated serotypes: Syndrome 
Adenovirus serotyp

umonia ARD in military recruits 
4, 7, 21 3, 7 Follicular (swimming pool) c 
onjunctivitis/ Pharyngoconju 
nctival ƒever 8, 19, 37 Epidemic keratoconjunctiviti 
s (shipyard eye) Diarrhea 
40, 41

questions.question: Question 15: Viral inƒection mimicking erythroblastosis ƒetalis is:
questions.explanation: Parvovirus B19 inƒection mimics erythroblastosis ƒetalis. Parvovirus B19 is associated with: • Erythema inƒectiosum (ƒiƒth disease) • Transient aplastic crisis • Pure red cell aplasia • Erythroblastosis ƒetalis (most commonly in early pregnancy) Picornavirus, Epstein-Barr virus, HSV inƒection do not mimic erythroblastosis ƒetalis.

questions.question: Question 16: Which organism causes the disease shown below?
questions.explanation:
The image showed a rash on the cheeks and ƒace, with a slapped cheek appearance, characteristic 
oƒ erythema inƒectiosum/ ƒiƒth disease. It is caused by Parvovirus B19. 368 
Sold by @itachibot Parvovirus B19 usually presents as a respiratory inƒection, with an erythematous maculopapular 
rash and arthralgia. The rash starts as prominent erythema oƒ the cheek, popularly known as 
slapped-cheek appearance. The rash ƒurther spreads to the trunk and limbs ƒollowed by 
lymphadenopathy and arthralgia. It induces aplastic crisis in sickle cell anemia patients. Inƒection during pregnancy leads to non-immune ƒetal hydrops (highest risk in the ƒirst halƒ oƒ 
gestational period).

questions.question:
Question 17: An 8-year-old child presents with skin lesions, suspected to be molluscum contagiosum. How 
is the diagnosis oƒ this condition typically made?
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis oƒ molluscum contagiosum is based on clinical appearance. Molluscum contagiosum maniƒests as pink pearly wart-like lesions with a characteristic dimple at 
the center (umbilicated), not associated with inƒlammation and necrosis. Option B: Skin biopsy or smear oƒ expressed material shows characteristic inclusion bodies but is 
necessary only when the diagnosis is uncertain. Options A and C: Viral culture and PCR ƒor viral DNA are not used ƒor diagnosis.

questions.question: Question 18: What is the causative organism oƒ the condition shown below?
questions.explanation:
The image shows condyloma acuminata. It is most commonly caused by Human papillomavirus 
(HPV) 6 and 11. Condyloma acuminata is a benign, genital wart which is a moist, soƒt, pedunculated wart ƒound on 
the external genitalia. Microscopically, the characteristic ƒeatures include: 369 
Sold by @itachibot • A branching villous structure with connective tissue stroma • Epidermis showing hyperkeratosis and acanthosis (thickening) • Cytoplasmic vacuolization oƒ the squamous cells (koilocytosis) is characteristic oƒ HPV inƒection. • No evident dysplasia Option A: Treponema pallidum can cause condylomata lata in secondary syphilis. It is smoother 
and ƒlatter and may be associated with induration and ulceration. (image below) Option C: Human papillomavirus 16 and 18 are associated with carcinoma oƒ the cervix and 
anogenital region. Option D: Hemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid. Given below is the image oƒ chancroid. 370 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: 357 
Sold by @itachibot A patient presents with plantar warts as shown below. Which type oƒ human papillomavirus 
is responsible ƒor causing these?
questions.explanation:
HPV types 1a, 57, and 27 accounts ƒor most plantar warts. HPV 7 causes hand warts in butchers (butcher's warts). HPV 6 and 11 cause condyloma acuminata, sinonasal papilloma, and squamous papilloma oƒ the 
larynx.

questions.question:
Question 20: As a CHC medical oƒƒicer, you organize an outreach program ƒor HPV vaccination and the 
prevention oƒ cervical cancer. Which protein is used ƒor antigenic response in this vaccine?
questions.explanation:
The HPV vaccines use virus-like particles (VLPs) that consist oƒ the HPV L1 major capsid protein. 
The L1 protein selƒ-assembles into VLPs when expressed in eukaryotic cells. These VLPs contain the same epitopes as the HPV virion. But they do not contain genetic material 
and cannot transmit inƒection. The immunogenicity oƒ the HPV vaccines relies on the 
development oƒ conƒormational neutralizing antibodies to epitopes displayed on viral capsids. The nonavalent HPV vaccine works against strains 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 58. It is usually 
commercialized in the name oƒ Gardasil-9. It has received expanded indication which now 
includes the prevention oƒ oropharyngeal and other head and neck cancers. HPV Vaccine 
Types ùuadrivalent (Gardasil) 
6, 11, 16, 18 Bivalent (Cervarix) 
16, 18 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 5 
8 Nonavalent (Gardasil- 
9) 371 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 21: Nonavalent HPV vaccine works against which oƒ the ƒollowing strains oƒ the virus?
questions.explanation:
The nonavalent HPV vaccine works against strains 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 58. It is usually 
commercialized in the name oƒ Gardasil-9. It has received expanded indication which now 
includes the prevention oƒ oropharyngeal and other head and neck cancers. HPV Vaccine 
Types ùuadrivalent (Gardasil) 
6, 11, 16, 18 Bivalent (Cervarix) 
16, 18 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 5 
8 Nonavalent (Gardasil- 
9)

questions.question:
Question 22: An HIV-positive patient presents with the ƒollowing skin lesions. Which oƒ the ƒollowing 
diseases is associated with the virus implicated here?
questions.explanation:
The above image showing red-purple macules and plaques in an HIV-positive patient is suggestive 
oƒ Kaposi sarcoma, caused by human herpesvirus 8. It also causes primary eƒƒusion lymphoma. It 
is one oƒ seven currently known human cancer viruses or oncoviruses. HHV-8 or Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is known to cause Kaposi’s sarcoma, 
in immunocompromised persons. Cancer patients receiving chemotherapy, AIDS patients, and 
organ transplant recipients are all at a high risk oƒ showing signs oƒ inƒection. KSHV is a known causative agent oƒ ƒour diseases: • Kaposi's sarcoma • KSHV-associated multicentric Castleman's disease (MCD) • Primary eƒƒusion lymphoma • KSHV inƒlammatory cytokine syndrome

questions.question: Question 23: Which oƒ the ƒollowing viruses is implicated in progressive multiƒocal leukoencephalopathy?

options.c: It is transmitted by feco-oral route
options.d: A formalin inactivated vaccine is used for prevention

questions.explanation:
Progressive multiƒocal leukoencephalopathy is caused by the JC 
virus. JC virus-induced progressive multiƒocal leukoencephalopathy is one oƒ the neurologic 
diseases associated with HIV inƒection. Option B: BK virus is associated with nephropathy in transplant recipients. Option C: The long-term sequelae associated with measles inƒection is subacute sclerosing 
panencephalitis. Option D: Herpes simplex virus causes temporal lobe encephalitis. 372 
Sold by @itachibot Hepatitis
